No, you can't use AP credits to waive college requirements unless specified (like R&C, Math 1A/1B etc.). So you'd have to take a HSS course to satisfy it (whether here or an approved CC course). Just an FYI, AP credits mean almost nothing outside of high school, so it's best not to depend on them or think about them as "backups."

---------------------------------------

**Note: the answer below is valid for students in EECS only.** **Only EECS/engineering students have "HSS" requirements; they are called breadth requirements for L&S students.**

According to https://engineering.berkeley.edu/academics/undergraduate-guide/degree-requirements/humanities-and-social-sciences, "A maximum of two of the six H/SS course requirements may be met by AP, IB or A-Level exam scores (in humanities and social sciences subjects)."

However, delving deeper into the AP courses that actually fulfill the requirements at https://engineering.berkeley.edu/academics/undergraduate-guide/exams, its clear that an AP course can only be used to fulfill R&C A or a lower division H/SS course, so I don't think you can benefit from your AP course anymore. :/

children.subject:
While you're in the unfortunate position that no, the ap credit cannot count, you can trawl the course catalog and find H/SS courses that you have familiarity in, reach out to the professor and use the Course Credit By Examination form to get a P/NP credit for the course, saving you from the requirement.

If you're not familiar, under Course Credit By Examination [CCBE], the professor agrees to certify your course knowledge by having you take a test -- sometimes you sit for the course's finals, sometimes you take a previous year's finals, or the professor makes a new exam that they feel is adequately preparatory. Most professors are totally opposed to doing this, but if you can explain your circumstances and demonstrate your desire effectively [and take dozens of rejections], you can probably find someone willing to do this for you. 

Ideally, find an easier course on BerkeleyTime.com and then email professors, though it should be noted it is exponentially easier to say no to an email than it is to say no to a person in a face-to-face meeting [so show up during the first week @ their office hours]. Thereafter, your engineering advisor can certify that the professor signed and agreed to this. Generally try and be accommodating and flexible, acknowledge the favor being done for you, and maybe read the course textbook for whatever one you pick and try and build an understanding beyond what's enough to pass.

AP = Lower division only.

You must take two upper division HSS courses here at Berkeley or an approved 4 year university. 

Please note that your R&C B course must be completed by the end of your sophomore year, otherwise enrollment will be blocked.

AP = Lower division only.

You must take two upper division HSS courses here at Berkeley or an approved 4 year university.

Is it possible for me to be exempt from one of the two UD HSS courses via AP Credit (assuming I still only pass out of a max of two courses from AP)?

My current HSS scheme is like follows:

1. RC A - AP Credit

2. RC B - Transfer Credit

3. HSS - Already took at Berkeley

4. HSS - Already took at Berkeley

5. UD HSS - AP Credit

6. UD HSS - Take at Berkeley

Would this work? Or would I have to actually take the UD HSS?
